```{r data generation, echo = FALSE, results = "hide"}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE)
options(scipen=100)

while(TRUE){
  la = sort(runif(2,0.01,0.99))
  n = sample(30:200,1)
  p = round(runif(1,0.01,0.99),2)
  mu = p
  sig = sqrt(p*(1-p))
  mut = mu*n
  sigt = sig*sqrt(n)
  siga = sig/sqrt(n)
  zapp = round(qnorm(la),2)
  xt1 = round(floor(mut+zapp[1]*sigt)+0.5,1)
  xt2 = round(floor(mut+zapp[2]*sigt)+0.5,1)
  phat1 = round(xt1/n,4)
  phat2 = round(xt2/n,4)
  z1 = (xt1-mut)/sigt
  z2 = (xt2-mut)/sigt
  z1lo = floor(z1*100)/100
  z1hi = ceiling(z1*100)/100
  z2lo = floor(z2*100)/100
  z2hi = ceiling(z2*100)/100
  
  la1 = pnorm(z1)
  la1lo = round(pnorm(z1lo),4)
  la1hi = round(pnorm(z1hi),4)
  la2 = pnorm(z2)
  la2lo = round(pnorm(z2lo),4)
  la2hi = round(pnorm(z2hi),4)
  
  ca = la2-la1
  calo = round(la2lo-la1lo,4)
  cahi = round(la2hi-la1hi,4)
  camin = round(la2hi-la1lo,4)
  camax = round(la2lo-la1hi,4)
  
  tol = max(abs(camax-camin)*1.1,0.001)
  if(n*p>10 & n*(1-p)>10 & ca>0){
    break
  }
}
```

Question
========

In some game, each trial has a $p = `r p`$ probability of success. A player will attempt `r n` trials. What is the probability that the proportion of successes is between `r phat1` and `r phat2`?

(Even though single trials are **not** normally distributed [they follow a [Bernoulli distribution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernoulli_distribution){target="_blank"}], the random proportion will be normally distributed.
See [central limit theorem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem){target="_blank"}.
Also, I have already made the [continuity correction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuity_correction){target="_blank"}. )


Solution
========

[video](https://vimeo.com/531943456){target="_blank"}

We determine the mean and standard deviation of the proportion sampling distribution.
$$\mu ~=~ p ~=~ `r mu`$$
$$\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(`r p`)(`r 1-p`)}{`r n`}} ~=~ `r siga` $$

We determine both $z$-scores. We get the first $z$-score.

$$\begin{aligned}
z_1 &= \frac{\hat{p}_1 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\
&= \frac{`r phat1`-`r mu`}{`r siga`} \\\\
&= `r z1`
\end{aligned}$$

We get the second $z$-score.

$$\begin{aligned}
z_2 &= \frac{\hat{p}_2 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\
&= \frac{`r phat2`-`r mu`}{`r siga`} \\\\
&= `r z2`
\end{aligned}$$

Then, find the standard normal probability.

$$P(`r z1` < Z < `r z2`) ~=~ `r ca` $$

Of course, you could have rounded the $z$-scores, so any of the following will also get credit.
$$P(`r z1lo` < Z < `r z2lo`) ~=~ `r calo` $$
$$P(`r z1hi` < Z < `r z2hi`) ~=~ `r cahi` $$
$$P(`r z1lo` < Z < `r z2hi`) ~=~ `r camax` $$
$$P(`r z1hi` < Z < `r z2lo`) ~=~ `r camin` $$
